image.altText: CLP leader Lia Finocchiaro standing in front of NT Parliament House and looking serious.

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Thursday, October 12.

title.children: NT leader says alternatives to Voice being prepped, Indigenous man turned away from polls over Yes shirt

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Lucas Forbes Sebastian and Ella McCorry are helping their fellow students get the right information ahead of the Voice referendum poll, amid concern about inaccurate social media posts. The eighteen-year-old Wiradjuri twins have been frustrated by misinformation about the Voice to Parliament referendum on TikTok and Facebook. They're part of their school's student representative council, which has been running Q & A sessions with younger students about the Voice. The council has also written to the parents of year 12 students, urging them to seek reliable information. Read more about Sebastian and Ella's work below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wiradjuri high schoolers fighting Voice misinformation

featuredLink.title: These twin high-schoolers say misinformation on the Voice is rampant among teens, so they're trying to fix that

children.content: The twins say some of their peers have been falsely told the Voice will raise rents.
(ABC Riverina: Lucas Forbes)
Reporting by Lucas Forbes
Sebastian and Ella McCorry
are helping their fellow students get the right information ahead of the Voice referendum poll, amid concern about inaccurate social media posts.
The eighteen-year-old Wiradjuri twins have been frustrated by misinformation about the Voice to Parliament referendum on TikTok and Facebook.
They're part of their school's student representative council, which has been running Q
A sessions with younger students about the Voice. The council has also written to the parents of year 12 students, urging them to seek reliable information.
Read more about Sebastian and Ella's work below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick The Northern Territory's Opposition Leader, Lia Finocchiaro, says she doesn't believe a Voice to Parliament will deliver change for remote NT communities and is confident a No vote will prevail in the territory. Speaking at a press conference, Ms Finocchiaro says her party, the Country Liberals, is preparing policies for the 2024 NT election to help "re-empower" the NT's remote communities, through "restoring community control of local government". "A CLP government that I lead is very committed to Aboriginal people living in the bush, in restoring, literally, their voice to our parliament," she said. "Local government reform is critical, and so we're out engaging … about how we can reshape local government to give back that decision-making and that voice in our remote communities." At a Yes campaign on Wednesday in Alice Springs, Chief Minister Natasha Fyles criticised Ms Finocchiaro's council plan, and said she was "simply making excuses" for voting against a Voice.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NT opposition leader says alternatives to Voice being prepared

children.content: NT opposition leader Lia Finocchiaro is spruiking alternatives to the Voice.
(ABC News: Michael Franchi)
Reporting by Matt Garrick
The Northern Territory's Opposition Leader,
Lia Finocchiaro
, says she doesn't believe a Voice to Parliament will deliver change for remote NT communities and is confident a
No vote will prevail in the territory
Speaking at a press conference, Ms Finocchiaro says her party, the
Country Liberals
, is preparing policies for the 2024 NT election to help "re-empower" the NT's remote communities, through "restoring community control of local government".
"A CLP government that I lead is very committed to Aboriginal people living in the bush, in restoring, literally, their voice to our parliament," she said.
"Local government reform is critical, and so we're out engaging … about how we can reshape local government to give back that decision-making and that voice in our remote communities."
At a Yes campaign on Wednesday in Alice Springs,
Chief Minister Natasha Fyles
criticised Ms Finocchiaro's council plan, and said she was "simply making excuses" for voting against a Voice.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yagara and Bundjalung elder, Uncle Valentine Brown, attended the Winston Glades polling station near Ipswich, west of Brisbane, on Tuesday. The 73-year-old said when he entered the polling station, official workers told him he wasn't allowed to vote while wearing a Yes shirt, but did not give him an explanation as to why. He was told to go home and change clothes if he wanted to cast his ballot. "We were just going around peacefully, doing our business to vote," Mr Brown said. In a statement, a spokesperson encouraged voters to not wear campaign clothing, as the law states people cannot campaign within 6 metres of a polling station. "If a voter simply wears campaign material (ie a pin or shirt) into the polling place, casts their vote and leaves, it likely won't contravene the act," the AEC spokesperson said. "However, if the voter wears that material into a polling place and is then seen talking with someone inside about it … that could be construed as campaigning."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Indigenous elder turned away from voting centre for wearing Yes shirt

featuredLink.title: Don't wear 'Yes' or 'No' clothing when you vote in the Voice referendum, AEC warns

children.content: Yagara elder Uncle Val says he was turned away from a polling booth in Ipswich
(ABC News: Victoria Pengilley)
Yagara and Bundjalung elder,
Uncle Valentine Brown
, attended the Winston Glades polling station near Ipswich, west of Brisbane, on Tuesday.
The 73-year-old said when he entered the polling station, official workers told him
he wasn't allowed to vote while wearing a Yes shirt, but did not give him an explanation as to why
He was told to go home and change clothes if he wanted to cast his ballot.
"We were just going around peacefully, doing our business to vote," Mr Brown said.
In a statement, a spokesperson encouraged voters to
not wear campaign clothing
, as the law states people cannot campaign within 6 metres of a polling station.
"If a voter simply wears campaign material (ie a pin or shirt) into the polling place, casts their vote and leaves, it likely won't contravene the act," the AEC spokesperson said.
"However, if the voter wears that material into a polling place and is then seen talking with someone inside about it … that could be construed as campaigning."

items.synopsis: Australian journalist Cheng Lei has returned to Australia and been reunited with her family — more than three years after she was first detained in China. Here's how the story unfolded.

title.children: Accused of 'supplying state secrets', Cheng Lei spent three years in a Chinese prison. Here's how she made it home

image.altText: People are watching a fire burn on top of the rubble of a residential building in Gaza.

items.synopsis: Israel cuts off Gaza's external electricity supply as part of its retaliation for the terror attacks perpetrated by Hamas in southern Israel over the weekend. Follow live.

title.children: Gaza power plant shuts down after running out of fuel

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A survivor of the Supernova music festival in Israel has given a chilling account of how he managed to escape terrorists by concealing himself in a hole for hours as gunfire raged around him. "I saw cars burned, bodies with bullet holes, bodies burned, bodies with knives inside of them," Omri Lendler told ABC Breakfast host Michael Rowland. While friends had been kidnapped or killed, he was lucky to escape with his life. "I found a large tree with a bush attached to it, I went under it and started digging myself a hole. I thought 'what can I do to conceal myself … as best as I could', and after about two hours that I was in the hole, I heard the sound of leaves and twigs cracking under someone's boot," he said. '"I told myself 'Omri don't move, breathe as little as you can', just hope he doesn’t see you and after a long 60 second silence I heard the sound of him approaching me and the sounds of twigs moving. "I was closing my eyes and I thanked everyone for the incredible life I had and I hoped that my mum and my family will be able to live a happy and fulfilling life without me." Fortunately, he wasn’t found. It wasn't until around five hours later that he emerged from his hiding spot once the shooting stopped and managed to find police back at the festival site. "I saw horrific stuff, I've seen cars burned, bodies burned, people that were shot at … the scene was horrific," he said. "It was not a battlefield … it was a bunch of innocent people that came to a party to have fun and celebrate life and were attacked by people who came to celebrate death."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I heard the sound of him approaching me': Music festival survivor tells account of how he escaped

children.content: A survivor of the
Supernova music festival
in Israel has given a chilling account of how he managed to escape terrorists by concealing himself in a hole for hours as gunfire raged around him.
"I saw cars burned, bodies with bullet holes, bodies burned, bodies with knives inside of them," Omri Lendler told ABC Breakfast host Michael Rowland.
While friends had been kidnapped or killed, he was lucky to escape with his life.

"I found a large tree with a bush attached to it, I went under it and started digging myself a hole. I thought 'what can I do to conceal myself … as best as I could', and after about two hours that I was in the hole, I heard the sound of leaves and twigs cracking under someone's boot," he said.

'"I told myself 'Omri don't move, breathe as little as you can', just hope he doesn’t see you and after a long 60 second silence I heard the sound of him approaching me and the sounds of twigs moving.
"I was closing my eyes and I thanked everyone for the incredible life I had and I hoped that my mum and my family will be able to live a happy and fulfilling life without me."
Fortunately, he wasn’t found.
It wasn't until around five hours later that he emerged from his hiding spot once the shooting stopped and managed to find police back at the festival site.
"I saw horrific stuff, I've seen cars burned, bodies burned, people that were shot at … the scene was horrific," he said.
"It was not a battlefield … it was a bunch of innocent people that came to a party to have fun and celebrate life and were attacked by people who came to celebrate death."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US is talking to Israel and Egypt about helping civilians get out of Gaza, but there's still no specific plan, according to the White House. "We believe that safe passage is important, and we want to see a safe passage corridor opened up," national security spokesman John Kirby told a press briefing here in Washington a little earlier. But he said he had no details to announce. "I can't tell you a specific route or a corridor. I just want to make it clear that we are actively working on this with our Egyptian and our Israeli counterparts." Mr Kirby said Hamas was to blame for the suffering of civilians under bombardment from Israel in Gaza. "Hamas is directly endangering their lives, headquartering themselves in hospitals and schools, residential buildings, using the Palestinian people as human shields."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US 'actively working' on safe route out of Gaza

children.content: The US is talking to Israel and Egypt about helping civilians get out of Gaza, but there's still no specific plan, according to the White House.
"We believe that safe passage is important, and we want to see a safe passage corridor opened up,"
national security spokesman John Kirby told a press briefing here in Washington a little earlier.
But he said he had no details to announce.
"I can't tell you a specific route or a corridor. I just want to make it clear that we are actively working on this with our Egyptian and our Israeli counterparts."

props.alt: John Kirby stands in front of the White House press briefing wall, with a US flag beside him and White House picture behind him.

children.content: White House national security spokesman John Kirby
(AP: Susan Walsh)
Mr Kirby said Hamas was to blame for the suffering of civilians under bombardment from Israel in Gaza.
"Hamas is directly endangering their lives, headquartering themselves in hospitals and schools, residential buildings, using the Palestinian people as human shields."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's ambassador to the UK remains unapologetic over his country's bombardment of Gaza, warning there will be no quick fix to the crisis following the weekend's terror attack by Hamas. Speaking to ABC's Michael Rowland from Tel Aviv, Mark Regev said Saturday's attack was a declaration of war. "The way they invaded, they butchered our people, killing innocent people in their homes, murdering children, what they did was a strategic attack on my country and they started this war and we will finish it," he said. Mr Ragev said while civilian casualties should be avoided at any cost, there was no way of avoiding it in this case. "There hasn't been a war in recent history which hasn't involved collateral damage and civilians, unfortunately, getting killed," he said. "If we can't hit them back, why would they stop?" He added that Israel authorities were urging the civilian population of Gaza to move away from Hamas strongholds. "They aren't our target, it is the Hamas military leadership and political structure," he said. "That is the target. It is going to be a war and wars are messy and we will lose people ourselves." He said the sort of barbarism that was committed by Hamas on Saturday morning was "reminiscent of ISIS-type terrorism". "We can no longer have our civilian population exposed to the sorts of barbarism violence that Hamas is capable of," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli ambassador says Hamas attack  'reminiscent of ISIS-type terrorism'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: PwC executives are up. Kevin Burrowes, PwC chief executive officer, has begun his evidence by reading from an opening statement. He's talked about the thousands of people PwC has employed over the decades, and the people it is proud to have trained. However, he says in January this year, the Tax Practitioners Board investigation into PwC revealed behaviour "we are not proud of". "What happened is totally unacceptable," he said. "We cannot apologise strongly enough for breaching the trust placed in us, and we accept the justifiable questions this raised about our trustworthiness and integrity, just as we commit to do better in the future," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC evidence begins

children.content: PwC executives are up.
Kevin Burrowes, PwC chief executive officer
, has begun his evidence by reading from an opening statement.
He's talked about the thousands of people PwC has employed over the decades, and the people it is proud to have trained.
However, he says in January this year, the
Tax Practitioners Board
investigation into PwC revealed behaviour "we are not proud of".
"What happened is totally unacceptable," he said.

"We cannot apologise strongly enough for breaching the trust placed in us, and we accept the justifiable questions this raised about our trustworthiness and integrity, just as we commit to do better in the future," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One of Australia’s biggest coal miners is facing an investor backlash over its plans to buy two massive mines from BHP. London-based hedge fund Bell Rock Capital Management this morning has launched a campaign to thwart Whitehaven Coal from purchasing the two Queensland operations for a reputed $US5 billion. It will attempt to mobilise shareholders to protest the purchase by voting against the executive pay deals up before the Whitehaven annual meeting in a fortnight. BHP has been steadily reducing its coal exposure with a view to a complete exit and in recent months has been in negotiations with Whitehaven to purchase the Daunia and Blackwater mines in central Queensland. Both mines are jointly owned by BHP and Mitsubishi and have been on the market since February. The London-based investor has kicked off the campaign this morning with letters to all Whitehaven shareholders and an advertising blitz in major newspapers. Bell Rock, which owns close to 5 per cent of Whitehaven, is incensed that a key hurdle for executive bonuses has been removed from this year’s AGM agenda which it claims will encourage Whitehaven executives to pursue growth via acquisitions at the expense of shareholder returns. The proposed mine purchases are likely to cost Whitehaven almost as much as the company is worth and will need to be funded by a massive increase in debt. While the Daunia mine produces metallurgical coal for steelmaking, a large portion of Blackwater’s output is thermal coal, the demand for which is declining as efforts to battle climate change escalate.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bell Rock Capital Management launches campaign to thwart Whitehaven Coal purchasing two mines

children.content: One of Australia’s biggest coal miners is facing an investor backlash over its
plans to buy two massive mines from BHP
London-based hedge fund
Bell Rock Capital Management
this morning has launched a campaign to thwart
Whitehaven Coal
from purchasing the two Queensland operations for a reputed $US5 billion.
It will attempt to mobilise shareholders to protest the purchase by voting against the executive pay deals up before the Whitehaven annual meeting in a fortnight.
BHP has been steadily reducing its coal exposure with a view to a complete exit and in recent months has been in negotiations with Whitehaven to purchase the
Daunia
and
Blackwater mines
in
central Queensland
. Both mines are jointly owned by
BHP
and
Mitsubishi
and have been on the market since February.
The London-based investor has kicked off the campaign this morning with letters to all Whitehaven shareholders and an advertising blitz in major newspapers.
Bell Rock, which owns close to 5 per cent of Whitehaven, is incensed that a key hurdle for executive bonuses has been removed from this year’s AGM agenda
which it claims will encourage Whitehaven executives to pursue growth via acquisitions at the expense of shareholder returns.
The proposed mine purchases are likely to cost Whitehaven almost as much as the company is worth and will need to be funded by a massive increase in debt.

While the Daunia mine produces metallurgical coal for steelmaking, a large portion of Blackwater’s output is thermal coal, the demand for which is declining as efforts to battle climate change escalate.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, After another positive trading session on Wall Street overnight, the ASX 200 index is expected to gain some value in this morning's session. PwC executives will face a parliamentary grilling in Canberra from 9am: Mr Kevin Burrowes, Chief Executive Officer Ms Jan McCahey, Chief Risk and Ethics Leader Ms Catherine Walsh, People Leader We'll also be hearing from the corporate regulator, the Professional Standards Councils, and Treasury officials.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC up at 9am

children.content: Good morning,
After another positive trading session on Wall Street overnight, the ASX 200 index is expected to gain some value in this morning's session.
PwC executives
will face a parliamentary grilling in Canberra from 9am:
Mr Kevin Burrowes, Chief Executive Officer
Ms Jan McCahey, Chief Risk and Ethics Leader
Ms Catherine Walsh, People Leader
We'll also be hearing from the
corporate regulator
, the Professional Standards Councils, and
Treasury
officials.
